publicationStmt.p: Working guidelines for the Digital Latin Library

sourceDesc.p: Born digital, with references to the Epidoc Guidelines

div.head: Structure of an LDLT Edition
div.p: This section describes the basic structure of the file that contains an edition for the Digital Latin Library's Library of Digital Latin Texts (LDLT). The structure of an LDLT edition resembles the structure of a traditional printed critical edition:

list.head: Parts of an LDLT Edition
list.item: Publication Details
Front Matter
Critical Text (including apparatus)
Indices

div.p: Since every text is unique, not every LDLT edition will have all of these sections. The nature of the text and the editor's judgment will determine the contents of an edition. The purpose of this section is to define the parts of an LDLT edition and provide guidelines for representing them in XML.
These guidelines are based on the standard established by the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI), with modification and customization to accommodate the special characteristics of Latin texts.
The following is an example of the general overall structure of an XML file for an LDLT edition:

availability.license: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

div.head: Preface
div.p: General introductory remarks about the edition.

div.head: List of Scholars Referred to By Name
Publication Details
div.p: A traditional critical edition in print has a title page announcing the title of the work, its author, the editor(s), and details of publication. In an LDLT edition, these details are presented as structured data within a TEI header (teiHeader). For example:

availability.license: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.

div.p: Since a critical edition is often based upon many sources (e.g., manuscripts, previous editions, commentaries, etc.), the teiHeader for an LDLT edition does not hew strictly to the TEI guidelines for sourceDesc. The sources for an LDLT edition are documented and described in the edition's front matter.
Just as an editor is not expected to create the title page and document the publication information, this section of an LDLT is the responsibility of the DLL staff.

div.head: Front Matter
div.p: The front contains divisions and subdivisions (using div) corresponding to the preface, bibliography, and conspectus for the edition.

The preface lays out (in prose, using p) the argument for the edition. It also describes the textual tradition and the major sources for it, which is why it is recommended to compile the bibliography first, to take advantage of the ability to link to individual entries in the bibliography, so that users will be able to have the information available as they read.

The elements available in all TEI documents are available for use in the preface. For example, an editor might want to make a table comparing the readings of manuscript families. In that case, the editor would use table and its related elements (see the TEI guidelines for table for more information).

div.head: Bibliography
div.p: The bibliography presents opportunities for leveraging the digital nature of an LDLT edition. For this reason, every item in the bibliography is encoded as structured data (contained in witness or bibl), so that the bibliography itself can become a useful tool for finding and using resources, especially those that are available online.

The bibliography is all the more useful as a tool if it is created and made available via Zotero, an open, online resource for building and managing bibliographies. It is highly recommended, but not required, that all LDLT editions have a corresponding Zotero repository for their bibliography.

div.head: Structure of the Bibliography
div.p: The bibliography should be organized according to the following structure:

list.head: Structure of the Bibliography for an LDLT Edition
list.item: Manuscripts (xml:id="bibliography-manuscripts")

Editions
Early Editions (xml:id="bibliography-editions-witnesses"
Modern Editions (xml:id="bibliography-editions-sources")
Secondary Sources (xml:id="bibliography-secondary-sources")

div.p: Additionally, there should be a list of the names of individual scholars (xml:id="bibliography-scholars") referred to by name in the apparatus, if they are not listed elsewhere in the bibliography (e.g., as the editor of an edition or author of an article). It is common, for example, to refer to a scholar whose unpublished notes appear in a commentary or who has corresponded with the editor. For ease of reference, these sources should be listed with information about where the information can be verified.

div.head: Human- and Machine-Readable Sigla, Symbols, and Abbreviations
div.p: Printed editions have long used a system of references for manuscripts and other materials in the bibliography. For example, single letters, or sigla, stand for manuscripts, and the last names of scholars stand for editions, commentaries, or other works of scholarship. Centuries of use have demontrated that this system of sigla and other symbols and abbreviations is an efficient, effective, and economical way of presenting the complex information contained in critical editions. Although its development was motivated by the constraints of the printed page, its virtues for representing data commend it for other media, too. But just as the printed page has limits, so too does the digital file, which means that the traditional system requires an update to make it available in a digital context.

Given some guidance and experience, people can learn how to navigate the system of letters, numbers, symbols, and other typographical conventions for referring to the sources of a crticial edition. If one edition uses superscript numerals to indicate the hands that wrote in a manuscript, but another uses superscript numerals to signify the number of a manuscript in a collection, a human reader can adjust to the difference in meaning without much effort. In contrast, machines need clear instructions and a reliable set of rules for reading a digital file. For example, a human might see N² and correctly interpret it within a particular edition as meaning "text written by the second in a succession of people who wrote in the manuscript known as codex Neapolitanus V A 8." Without explicit instructions, a machine will interpret the same information as simply the letter "N" with a superscript numeral 2 next to it. Indeed, a less experienced human reader might reach the same conclusion as the machine.

Since the audience for LDLT editions includes an entirely new class of reader (i.e., machines), it stands to reason that the reference system should be adapted to accommodate the needs of the expanded readership. For this reason, LDLT editions encode sigla and other aspects of the traditional reference system in two ways: a machine-readable version (using xml:id) and a human-readable version (using abbr, with special instructions for rendering typographical conventions such as superscript and subscript notation). In some cases, the values for both will be the same, but the strict rules of the XML specification for xml:id do not allow for the traditional system of combining letters with superscript and/or subscript numerals. Nevertheless, the values of xml:id and abbr should be similar, if not identical, to each other, and they should be meaningful. Editors should follow the conventions in previous editions of the same text, changing a siglum only if it is important to the edition's argument to do so. If the text has never been edited, the editor should choose sigla according to the principles outlined by West (74–75). In brief, use sigla that have mnemonic value (e.g., "V" for "Vaticanus" or "P" for "Parisinus").
Because the needs of editors will vary from edition to edition, the LDLT does not have strict rules for representing manuscript hands or similar information. Rather, we offer these suggestions:

row.cell: Multiple books or articles by the same scholar

div.p: In short, every entry, regardless of type, in the bibliography of an LDLT edition must have values for both xml:id and label. Otherwise, the edition will not be able to make full use of the digital format. Morever, if an entry lacks an abbr, it will not be available for a print version of the edition, should one be required.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: The description of manuscripts is a discipline unto itself, with long-established conventions for capturing all of the details about not only a manuscript's contents, but also its dimensions, provenance, material, and other physical details. It is customary for critical editions to provide a brief prose description of the major manuscripts used for establishing the text, usually only enough to identify where the manuscript may be found for consultation, but sometimes including information about its provenance and other details relevant to the edition (e.g., manuscript hands).

The prose format for describing manuscripts is a predictable and efficient way of conveying this information to human readers, but it is not useful for making the information available to machines for processing. That is why the TEI guidelines have an entire module for making manuscript descriptions available as structured data for machine-readability (10 Manuscript Description). The following guidelines are a customization of that module for LDLT editions.

These guidelines establish a minimum requirement for describing a manuscript for an LDLT edition so that the information can be processed and displayed as expected. They also include instructions for encoding a finer degree of detail. Above all, the point is to make the information available to both human and machine readers, so it is up to individual editors to use their best judgment regarding the amount of information that will be relevant to those seeking to understand the place of a manuscript in the tradition.

div.head: Structured Data
div.p: The TEI's module for manuscript description offers a model for presenting nearly every imaginable detail about a manuscript as structured data. Editors may wish to use more of the features of the module than are described here, but the following support the functionality of the LDLT viewer.

listWit (list of witnesses) contains the descriptions of manuscript witnesses for the edition. Separate listWit elements may be used to distinguish families of manuscripts. If it is desirable to use a siglum to refer to the consensus of manuscripts in that family, listWit must have xml:id and abbr with values corresponding to that siglum.

witness groups the information about a single manuscript, including the name used to refer to the manuscript in the edition (e.g., Codex Neapolitanus V A 8). Its xml:id is the unique machine-readable identifier to be used when referring to the manuscript's data (e.g., in the wit of a rdg in the apparatus criticus).
abbr (abbreviation) with type="siglum" contains the human-readable siglum that should be displayed on screen or printed Any superscript or subscript characters should be encoded using hi.
msDesc (manuscript description) groups the elements that compose the description of the manuscript:

list.head: Required Elements in msDesc
list.item: msIdentifier (manuscript identifier) groups information about the location and inventory number of the manuscript.
settlement contains the common English name of the place (e.g., Florence, not Firenze) where the manuscript is located.
repository contains the name of the library or other institution that houses the manuscript. Use the original name of the institution (e.g., Biblioteca Ambrosiana), not an English translation.

idno (identifier) contains the catalog or inventory information for the manuscript, including the name of the collection (e.g., Ottobonianus 1466). The point is to give enough information for a reader to be able to request more information about it.

altIdentifier (alternative identifier) contains other information (i.e., in addition to the idno) used to identify the manuscript. For example, the manuscript may have been recataloged, but its old number is still used.
msContents (manuscript contents) contains a prose description (using p) of the manuscript's contents, including incipits and explicits. Encode each work with bibl with author and title
phsyDesc (physical description) groups information about the manuscript.

objectDesc (object description) contains a prose description (using p) of the manuscript's physical characteristics (e.g., material(s), size, pagination, lines per page, etc.). It is up to the editor to decide how to present this information, but it is recommended to adopt a pattern and use it consistently (e.g., "Parchment: 261 X 160 mm.: 116 leaves: 38 verses per page"). Note that the TEI module for manuscript description has tags for these details. Editors may use them, but they will not affect the display or functionality of the LDLT edition.
handDesc (hand description) groups information about the distinct hands that wrote in the manuscript. Use hands with the value of the number of hands detectable in the manuscript.

handNote contains a prose description (using p) of a hand that wrote in the manuscript. Each handNote has an xml:id with a unique identifier (based on the xml:id of the manuscript) and an abbr with a human-readable version of the value of the hand's xml:id (see above for more on sigla).
history groups information about the date of the manuscript.
origin contains a prose description (using p) of the manuscript's date. Enclose the date with origDate with notAfter and notBefore.
provenance contains a prose description (using p) of the manuscript's provenance, if available.

div.p: The absolute minimum required for LDLT editions can be met with listWit, witness, and abbr:

listWit.witness: N = Codex Neapolitanus V A 8, saec. XV
G = Codex Gaddianus pl. 90, 12 inf., saec. XV

div.p: That example provides enough human- and machine-readable information to identify the manuscripts in the apparatus criticus, but it leaves much to be desired by anyone hoping to learn more about the manuscripts, or even locate them for private study.
The following uses all of the elements listed above to provide rich human- and machine-readable information about the same manuscripts:

listWit.witness:
N = Codex Neapolitanus V A 8
Naples Biblioteca Nazionale di Napoli V A 8
380
1–36ʳ contain Cato's De Agricultura; 20–101ʳ, Varro's De Re Rustica; 101ʳ–115ᵛ, the Bucolica of Calpurnius and Nemesianus.
The individual poems lack titles, but they are separated from each other by brief spaces. The following subscription appears at the end of the whole work: Aureliani Nemesiani Cartag̅ bucol’ explicit: Deo gratias amen. Finally, another more recent hand, as Bursian and Schenkl recognized, wrote Calpurnii eclogae and Nemesiani eclogae. The remaining leaves are blank.
Parchment: 261 X 160 mm.: 116 leaves: 38 verses per page.
With respect to correcting hands, two in particular stand out:
N1 belongs to the original copyist. See above for a detailed description of this hand's activity. N2: The manuscript was corrected again around the same time, but here and there the second hand cannot easily be distinguished from the first. N3: a third hand's emendations can be discerned in only a few places.
The manuscript was written at about the beginning of the fifteenth century.
We know nothing about the origin and provenance of this manuscript except what is understood from the following passages written on the last leaf: Joannes Antonius Perillus patric. neap. ac iuvenis apprime litteratus Jacobum Perillum hoc libro donavit MDCVII, Klis Juniis ("Joannes Antonius Perillus, a nobleman of Naples and most learned gentleman, gave this book to Jacob Perillus in 1667 on the first of June"), and a little below, Antonii Seripandi ex Jacobi Perilli amici opt. munere ("This book belongs to Antonius Seripandus, received as a gift from his best friend Jacob Perillus"). Later it was brought to the library of San Giovanni a Carbonara, and from there it came to the greatest library in Naples, formerly known as the Reale biblioteca borbonica, (now the Biblioteca nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III).

G = Codex Gaddianus pl. 90, 12 inf.
Florence Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana plut. 90, 12 inf.
It contains the twelve eclogues of Francesco Petrarch (ff. 1–44), the Culex of Vergilius Maro, the Dirae of Vergilius Maro (ff. 52–55), and Calpurnius and Nemesianus (ff. 55–74). A very brief, unattributed eclogue follows with the interlocutors Daphnis, Tityrus, Mopsus, and Meliboeus.
The following inscription has been added to the eclogues of Calpurnius: Egloge Calfurnii ad nemesianum cartaginiensem. (The Eclogues of Calfurnius to Nemesianus of Carthage). Nemesianus follows Calpurnius with the following title prefixed: Aureliani nemesiani cartaginiensis egloghe incipiunt (Here begin the eclogues of Aurelianus Nemesianus of Carthage). At the end of each eclogue there appears an explicit with the number of each eclogue, but Calpurnius' sixth eclogue lacks a subscription, and the following is written at the end of the seventh: explicit sexta egloga Calphurnii (Here ends the sixth eclogue of Calphurnius). This is explained by the fact that the seventh eclogue follows the sixth without any break, with the result that only six eclogues are attributed to Calpurnius in this manuscript. But in the margin, where the sixth eclogue ought to end, the copyist has added the following: aliqui volunt dicere quod ista sit alia et diversa egloga ubi incipit "lentus," aliqui dicunt quod est una etc. (Some wish to say that the eclogue that begins lentus is a completely different eclogue; others say that it is the same, etc.).
Paper: 294 X 225 mm.: 74 leaves. Individual pages generally have 29 verses, but some vary, with the shorter ones having 26 and the longer ones haveing 32 verses.
G1: The copyist himself added almost all of the corrections either by removing scribal errors in the verses or adding variant readings to the margin. See above for a more detailed description of this hand's activity. G2: Some corrections seem to have been made by another hand.
Written at the beginning of the fifteenth century.

div.head: Other Sources
div.p: The bibliography for early editions, modern editions, commentaries, translations, articles, notes, and other materials cited in the edition should be formatted according to latest edition of The Chicago Manual of Style. As noted elsewhere in these guidelines, it is recommended that editors use Zotero to manage the bibliography for LDLT editions, not least because Zotero can export the bibliography in Chicago style.

Items should be categorized and listed in groups for ease of reference. For example, previous editions should be listed separately from commentaries and articles. Depending on the nature of the material, it may be useful to subdivide previous editions into early and modern editions.

In keeping with the goal of human- and machine-readability, individual items in the bibliography should also be encoded in XML. To meet the minimum requirement for LDLT editions, individual items in the bibliography should be enclosed with bibl and they should have human- and machine-readable abbreviations (sigla), using abbr and xml:id respectively. See the section on sigla for more information.

listBibl.head: Previous Editions
listBibl.bibl: Barth 1613 = Barthius, Casparus. Venatici et Bucolici Poetae Latini: Gratius, Nemesianus, Calpurnius. Hanoviae: In Bibliopolio Willieriano, 1613.
Ulit. = Ulitius, Ianus. Venatio Novantiqua. Leidae: Ex Officina Elzeveriana, 1645.

div.p: For maximum functionality, it is strongly recommended to encode a greater degree of bibliographical detail, using the following:

list.item: editor or author
pubPlace (place of publication)
ptr (pointer, for the URL of a digital copy, if available)

div.p: The following sections demonstrate the recommended encoding for common types of records in a bibliography.

div.head: Editions
div.p: To make the most of the functionality supported by the LDLT and to remain true to its data model, previous editions should be classified in one of two categories: early editions based on a single manuscript, and modern critical editions based on more than one source. This will have consequences for how the editions are handled in the apparatus criticus (see below, Apparatus Criticus). The distinction should be preserved in the bibliography with the use of two different kinds of lists: listWit for early editions, and listBibl for modern editions. In both types of list, the items should be presented in chronological order.

div.head: Early Editions
div.p: Since it is often the case that an early edition is a witness to a single manuscript that might otherwise be lost, they are encoded in the bibliography with witness. Accordingly, they must be grouped in listWit. Since they are also printed books, they also require the use of bibl and its related elements.
listWit (list of witnesses) contains bibliographical records for early editions.
witness groups the information about an individual edition. xml:id provides the machine-readable abbreviation for the edition.
abbr (abbreviation) contains the human-readable abbreviation for the record, i.e., how the edition is referred to in the apparatus criticus.
bibl (bibliographic citation) contains the following bibliographical information about the edition:

list.item: editor contains the name of the editor in the form "Last name, First name," if known. If the name is in Latin, it should not be translated. If the name is not known, editor contains the word "Anonymous."
title contains either the name by which the edition is commonly known (e.g., editio Romana, editio Aldina) and/or the actual title of the edition.

pubPlace (place of publication) contains the name of the place where the edition was published, as it appears on the title page (e.g., Lipsiae instead of Leipzig). If the place is unknown, the value should be "s.l." (sine loco). If the place is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the place name in square brackets.

publisher contains the name of the publisher, as it appears on the title page. If the publisher's name is unknown, the value should be "s.n." (sine nomine). If the publisher is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the publisher's name in square brackets.

date contains the date in arabic numerals (e.g., 1504, not MDIV or CIↃIↃIV). If the date is unknown, the value should be "s.d." (sine die). If the date is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the date in square brackets.
ptr (pointer) has target with the URL of a digital copy of the edition, if one exists.

div.head: Modern Editions
div.p: The bibliography for modern editions follows the same pattern as that for early editions, except listBibl is used instead of listWit.
listBibl (citation lists) contains bibliographical records for modern editions.
bibl (bibliographic citation) has xml:id with the machine-readable abbreviation for the edition. It contains the following bibliographical information about the edition:

list.item: abbr (abbreviation) contains the human-readable abbreviation for the record, i.e., how the edition is referred to in the apparatus criticus.

editor contains the name of the editor in the form "Last name, First name," if known. If the name is in Latin, it should not be translated. If the name is not known, editor contains the word "Anonymous."
title contains either the name by which the edition is commonly known (e.g., editio Romana, editio Aldina) and/or the actual title of the edition.

pubPlace (place of publication) contains the name of the place where the edition was published, as it appears on the title page (e.g., Lipsiae instead of Leipzig). If the place is unknown, the value should be "s.l." (sine loco). If the place is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the place name in square brackets.

publisher contains the name of the publisher, as it appears on the title page. If the publisher's name is unknown, the value should be "s.n." (sine nomine). If the publisher is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the publisher's name in square brackets.

date contains the date in arabic numerals (e.g., 1504, not MDIV or CIↃIↃIV). If the date is unknown, the value should be "s.d." (sine die). If the date is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the date in square brackets.

div.head: Other Sources
div.p: Bibliographical information for items other than editions should gathered in a general bibliography (using listBibl), formatted according to the most recent edition of The Chicago Manual of Style, and presented in alphabetical order.
The following sections provide instructions for encoding different types of resources commonly found in the bibliographies of critical editions.

div.head: Books
div.p: Information about books, commentaries, monographs, collections of essays, etc., should be encoded with the following tags:
bibl (bibliographic citation) has xml:id with the machine-readable abbreviation for the book. It contains the following bibliographical information about the book:

list.item: abbr (abbreviation) contains the human-readable abbreviation for the record, i.e., how the book is referred to in the apparatus criticus.

author contains the name of the author in the form "Last name, First name," if known. If the name is in Latin, it should not be translated. If the name is not known, author contains the word "Anonymous."
title contains either the name by which the edition is commonly known (e.g., editio Romana, editio Aldina) and/or the actual title of the edition.

pubPlace (place of publication) contains the name of the place where the edition was published, as it appears on the title page (e.g., Lipsiae instead of Leipzig). If the place is unknown, the value should be "s.l." (sine loco). If the place is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the place name in square brackets.

publisher contains the name of the publisher, as it appears on the title page. If the publisher's name is unknown, the value should be "s.n." (sine nomine). If the publisher is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the publisher's name in square brackets.

date contains the date in arabic numerals (e.g., 1504, not MDIV or CIↃIↃIV). If the date is unknown, the value should be "s.d." (sine die). If the date is known, but not explicitly printed in the edition, put the date in square brackets.
ptr (pointer) has target with the URL of a digital copy of the edition, if one exists.

div.head: Articles
div.p: As with other items in the bibliography, articles in journals and periodicals should be formatted according to the latest edition of The Chicago Manual of Style. The minimum required encoding for articles is as follows:

egXML.bibl: Lucas = Lucas, Hans. "Zu Calpurnius." Wiener Studien 22 (1901): 139–40. URL: https://books.google.com/books?id=gbmMVZEcoGMC&pg=PA139#v=onepage&q&f=false.

div.p: However, it is strongly recommended to encode more details.
bibl (bibliographic citation) has xml:id with the machine-readable abbreviation for the book. It contains the following bibliographical information about the book:

list.item: abbr (abbreviation) contains the human-readable abbreviation for the record, i.e., how the book is referred to in the apparatus criticus.
author contains the name of the author in the form "Last name, First name."
title with level="a" contains the title of the article. Quotation marks for the title should be outside of title (e.g., "<title>Article Title</title>", not <title>"Article Title"</title>).
title with level="j" contains the title of the journal or periodical.

biblScope (scope of bibliographic reference) is used with unit to indicate details of publication:
unit="volume" contains the volume number of the journal in which the article has been published
unit="page" contains the inclusive pages where the article may be found
date contains the year of publication
ptr with target provide the URL of a digital copy of the article, if available.

egXML.bibl: Lucas = Lucas, Hans. "Zu Calpurnius." Wiener Studien 22 (1901): 139–40. URL: .

div.p: Note that a review of an edition or other work should be handled in the same way as a journal article, with the exception that the title should begin with the words "Review of" followed by the title of the work being reviewed.

egXML.bibl: Jacoby = Jacoby, Karl. Review of 'Calpurnii et Nemesiani Bucolica recensuit Henricus Schenkl, Lipsiae, G. Freytag, Pragae, F. Tempsky, 1885'. Wochenschrift für klassiche Philologie 3 (1886): 1287–94. URL: .

div.head: List of Scholars
div.p: Occasionally it is necessary to refer to a scholar whose unpublished work has been quoted or paraphrased elsewhere. For example, editors often cite Heinsius' unpublished conjectures, found in books in his own library. But "Heins." does not help a reader find more information, which is why the bibliography of an LDLT edition includes a list of scholars mentioned by name in the edition, with information about where to find more information, if they are available.
listPerson with xml:id="bibliography-scholars" groups the information identifying the scholars.
person with xml:id as described above groups information about an individual.

persName (personal name) groups the information about an individuals's name. For identification purposes, it is helpful, but not required, to use ref with the Virtual International Authorify File (VIAF) permalink for that person. The following information is contained by persName

list.item: abbr contains the name or abbreviated name used to refer to the person in the edition (e.g., Heins.).
forename contains the scholar's first and middle names (middle name optional), or initials, of the scholar. A separate forename should be used for the first and middle names.
surname contains the scholar's last name.

addname (additional name) contains an additional or alternate name by which a scholar is known. If a scholars is commonly known by a Latinized form of his or her name, that name should be inserted in addname.

div.p: note contains further information about the nature of the citation (e.g., "personal correspondence with editor"), with ref (reference) containing a reference to the entry in the bibliography that has citations of the scholar. target with the xml:id of that entry will point the reader to that entry.
These references will be rendered on a display and in print as follows:

list.head: Scholars Cited in this Edition
list.item: Heins. = Nicolaus Heinsius. Cited in Burman 1731.

div.head: Edition Text
div.p: The edition text corresponds to the text printed "above the line" of the apparatus in a traditional edition. It is composed of lemmata, that is, text judged by the editor to be authentic, accurate, and/or authoritative.

There may be more than one authoritative version of a text, depending on the text and depending on the approach adopted by the editor. Authors sometimes edit and revise their work over time. Scribes often record the version of the text that makes sense in their context. Scholars and other readers offer conjectures for problematic passages. But an editor must make decisions about the text an edition presents to readers. Combined, those decision constitute the editor's argument about the text, and they are on display in the official edition text in its initial state.

"Initial state" is an important phrase. Since the online version of an LDLT allows readers to swap readings from the critical apparatus into the main text, it is possible to encounter many versions of the text in one viewing of it, but the official edition text in its default initial state (i.e., what you see when you open the edition for the first time) is the starting point for those interactions.
This section establishes guidelines for encoding the information typically found in the main text of a critical edition.

div.head: Prose
div.p: The aim of this section is to provide guidance for marking up the structure of prose texts, using the generic model of book, chapter, and paragraph for the main components of a work.

In a traditional critical edition, numbers are printed in the margin and/or in the text itself. It is often unclear whether the numbers are meant to mark syntactic units, reflect the numbering of pages or sections in a canonical edition, or something else entirely. An advantage to semantically encoding the reference scheme is that it makes the scheme's significance explicit. For that reason, a human- and machine-readable reference scheme is essential for an LDLT edition. Moreover, if the structure is not encoded according to these guidelines, search and browse functionality will not be supported.

For an LDLT edition of a prose text, the top-level div has the type "edition"; this division contains the entire text of the edition. The next div will normally have the type "textpart" with subtype "book" and n to indicate the number of the book. If a different division scheme is required, editors should consult the DLL staff.
milestone may be used to mark the sections of a canonical edition, if the current edition uses a different scheme.

p (paragraph) contains the text of a chapter or other basic section in a prose work. n must be used to reflect the numbering scheme of the edition. Note that the TEI Guidelines define the paragraph as the fundamental organizational unit for all prose texts. The unique characteristics of some texts may require a different approach. In those cases, editors should work with DLL staff to identify the best way to encode the text in question.
seg (segment) contains a segment of a paragraph (e.g., a sentence or a more general "section"). If seg is used, n must be used to reflect the numbering scheme of the edition.

p.seg: Gallia est omnis divisa in partes tres, quarum unam incolunt Belgae, aliam Aquitani, tertiam qui ipsorum lingua Celtae, nostra Galli appellantur.
Hi omnes lingua, institutis, legibus inter se differunt. Gallos ab Aquitanis Garumna flumen, a Belgis Matrona et Sequana dividit.

Horum omnium fortissimi sunt Belgae, propterea quod a cultu atque humanitate provinciae longissime absunt, minimeque ad eos mercatores saepe commeant atque ea quae ad effeminandos animos pertinent important, proximique sunt Germanis, qui trans Rhenum incolunt, quibuscum continenter bellum gerunt.
Qua de causa Helvetii quoque reliquos Gallos virtute praecedunt, quod fere cotidianis proeliis cum Germanis contendunt, cum aut suis finibus eos prohibent aut ipsi in eorum finibus bellum gerunt.

Eorum una, pars, quam Gallos obtinere dictum est, initium capit a flumine Rhodano, continetur Garumna flumine, Oceano, finibus Belgarum, attingit etiam ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, vergit ad septentriones.
Belgae ab extremis Galliae finibus oriuntur, pertinent ad inferiorem partem fluminis Rheni, spectant in septentrionem et orientem solem.
Aquitania a Garumna flumine ad Pyrenaeos montes et eam partem Oceani quae est ad Hispaniam pertinet; spectat inter occasum solis et septentriones.

div.p: That text will be rendered as follows:
Liber I

Gallos ab Aquitanis Garumna flumen, a Belgis Matrona et Sequana dividit. 3Horum omnium fortissimi sunt Belgae, propterea quod a cultu atque humanitate provinciae longissime absunt, minimeque ad eos mercatores saepe commeant atque ea quae ad effeminandos animos pertinent important, proximique sunt Germanis, qui trans Rhenum incolunt, quibuscum continenter bellum gerunt. 4Qua de causa Helvetii quoque reliquos Gallos virtute praecedunt, quod fere cotidianis proeliis cum Germanis contendunt, cum aut suis finibus eos prohibent aut ipsi in eorum finibus bellum gerunt. 5Eorum una, pars, quam Gallos obtinere dictum est, initium capit a flumine Rhodano, continetur Garumna flumine, Oceano, finibus Belgarum, attingit etiam ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, vergit ad septentriones. 6Belgae ab extremis Galliae finibus oriuntur, pertinent ad inferiorem partem fluminis Rheni, spectant in septentrionem et orientem solem. 7Aquitania a Garumna flumine ad Pyrenaeos montes et eam partem Oceani quae est ad Hispaniam pertinet; spectat inter occasum solis et septentriones.

div.head: Verse
div.p: The verse module of the TEI Guidelines offers many possibilities for marking up various aspects of prosody, but the LDLT is primarily concerned with the core tags for encoding the structure of verse texts. This does not mean that editors and others should avoid using the verse module. It means only that the LDLT does not provide functionality for that level of detail.

For an LDLT edition of a verse text, the top-level div has the type "edition"; this division contains the entire text of the edition. The next div will normally have the type "textpart" with subtype "book" and n to indicate the number of the book. div with type="poem" contains the parts of a single poem (e.g., stanzas or lines). If there is more than one poem in a book, n should be used to number the poems. met with the name of the meter may also be used, if the editor wishes to identify the meter. If a different division scheme is required, editors should consult the DLL staff.
lg (line group) groups one or more verse lines that form a stanza or a couplet; type may be used to identify the grouping (e.g., "stanza" or "couplet").
l (line) contains the text of a single line of verse, with n and the number of the line.

lg.l: bellique causas et vitia et modos

div.head: Dialogue
div.p: Texts that feature interlocutors (e.g., drama, dialogue) should be encoded using sp and speaker.
sp (speech) groups elements related to a person or character's speech.
who is used with sp to identify the speaker.
speaker contains a human-readable label identifying the person or character speaking the text.
These features can be used in verse and prose texts:

sp.speaker: C.
sp.l: Nondum Solis equos declinis mitigat aestas,
quamvis et madidis incumbant prela racemis
et spument rauco ferventia musta susurro.
cernis ut ecce pater quas tradidit, Ornyte, vaccae
molle sub hirsuta latus explicuere genista?
nos quoque vicinis cur non succedimus umbris?
torrida cur solo defendimus ora galero?

sp.speaker: Laelius
sp.p: Atqui, Cato, gratissimum nobis, ut etiam pro Scipione pollicear, feceris, si, quoniam speramus, volumus quidem certe, senes fieri, multo ante a te didicerimus quibus facillime rationibus ingravescentem aetatem ferre possimus.

sp.speaker: Cato
sp.p: Faciam vero, Laeli, praesertim si utrique vestrum, ut dicis, gratum futurum est.

div.head: People
div.p: It can be useful to encode names of people mentioned in the text of an edition, whether to facilitate the creation of an index or to support digital search functionality. It is up to the editor to decide which names, if any, should be encoded. If names are to be encoded, the following guidelines should be observed.
listPerson (list of persons) contains a list of names of people mentioned in the text. This list must be maintained by the editor as names are encoded in the edition.

person contains the nominative form of the name of a person mentioned in the text. It must also have xml:id with a machine-readable version of the name to serve as a reference point for instances of the name in the text.
persName contains the name of a person, regardless of case.
note contains further identifying information about the person (e.g., dates, the ID number in a reference work or prosopography), if the name is not enough to make the distinction.

Since names may appear in different cases in the text, it is vital to have a reference list of names in the nominative form. While working on a text, editors should consider which names, if any, should appear in an index and establish a working list of names in the nominative case. At this stage, it is worthwhile to start an XML document for names, using listPerson, person, and persName as described above:
Where names of people in the reference list appear in the edition text, they should be encoded with persName and ref pointing to the xml:id of the person.

egXML.l: constat ab Absyrti caede fuisse loco.

div.p: It is also possible to encode indirect references to people:

div.head: Places
div.p: Place names, and the names of those who inhabit the places, can be encoded in LDLT editions to facilitate creation of an index or to assist readers in identifying the places mentioned in the text. If it is desirable to encode this information, the following guidelines should be followed.
placeName contains the name of a place, with ref and the canonical Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for it at Pleiades.
orgName (organization name) contains the name of the inhabitants of a place, with ref and the canonical Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) for the place at Pleiades.
The following is an extreme example, but it demonstrates what might be encoded and how.

Qua de causa Helvetii quoque reliquos Gallos virtute praecedunt, quod fere cotidianis proeliis cum Germanis contendunt, cum aut suis finibus eos prohibent aut ipsi in eorum finibus bellum gerunt. Eorum una, pars, quam Gallos obtinere dictum est, initium capit a flumine Rhodano, continetur Garumna flumine, Oceano, finibus Belgarum, attingit etiam ab Sequanis et Helvetiis flumen Rhenum, vergit ad septentriones. div.head: Symbols Commonly Used in the Text of a Critical Edition
div.p: The symbols in this section have been gleaned from Martin West, Textual Criticism and Editorial Technique (Stuttgart, 1973), 80–81. Many of the symbols will be useful only for diplomatic transcriptions of documentary sources, but they are included here in an attempt to be comprehensive. Editors who need to use other special symbols should consult with LDLT staff.

For the sake of uniformity, this section follows closely Tom Elliott, Gabriel Bodard, Elli Mylonas, Simona Stoyanova, Charlotte Tupman, Scott Vanderbilt, et al. (2007-2014), EpiDoc Guidelines: Ancient documents in TEI XML (Version 8). Available: http://www.stoa.org/epidoc/gl/latest.

div.head: Abbreviation Fully Expanded
div.p: ( ) = The LDLT follows the Epidoc guidelines for encoding fully expanded abbreviations :
expan (expansion) contains the full expansion of an abbreviation.
abbr (abbreviation) contains the abbreviated part, i.e. the letters actually on the page.
ex (editorial expansion) contains a sequence of letters added by an editor or transcriber when expanding an abbreviation.
Multiple <abbr> elements within a single <expan> compose a single abbreviation between them. For example, e.g. is one abbreviation for the phrase "exempli gratia."

div.head: Text added by emendation
div.p: < > = An editor supplies text believed to be missing from the original source. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines "Editorial Restoration: Characters Lost But Restored By Modern Editor" )
supplied signifies text believed by the transcriber or editor to be missing.
reason indicates that text has been omitted, but supplied by emendation.

div.head: Undetermined Amount Of Text Lost
div.p: [ ] = Text has been lost from one or more witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Characters, Quantity Unknown" )
gap signifies text missing because of damage.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
extent with value "unknown" indicates that an undetermined amount of text has been lost.
unit with value "characters" indicates that an unspecified number of characters (whether single characters or words or larger groups of text) have been lost.

div.head: Known Amount Of Text Lost
div.p: [ . . . ] = The editor or transcriber knows from context and/or observation how much text has been lost. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Characters, Quantity Known" )
gap signifies text missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
quantity indicates the amount of text has been lost.
unit indicates the unit measured in quantity.
Each dot represents a missing character.

div.head: Known Number of Lines Lost
div.p: [------] = A known quantity of lines has been lost, or is conjectured to have been lost from the text of all witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Lines, Quantity Known" )
gap signifies that text is missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
quantity indicates the number of lines missing.
unit with value "line" indicates the unit measured in quantity.
Note that the brackets and the dashes represent one missing line. The number in quantity will determine the number of instances of that group of characters, one per line.

div.head: Unknown Number of Lines Lost
div.p: - - - - - - = An unknown quantity of lines has been lost, or is conjectured to have been lost from the text of all witnesses. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Lost Lines, Quantity Unknown" )
gap signifies that text is missing.
reason with value "lost" indicates that the text has been lost.
extent with value "unknown" indicates that nothing more is known about the amount of text that has been lost.
unit with value "line" indicates the unit measured in extent.

div.head: Editorial Deletion
div.p: { } = Text suspected by the editor to be superfluous, but retained in the main text to indicate its traditional attribution to the author. (Cf. Epidoc guidelines, "Superfluous Text" )

Square brackets have been used to indicate editorial deletions in the past, but, as West argues (p. 80), this is apt to cause confusion, since they have a different meaning for papyrologists and epigraphists (see "Undetermined Amount Of Text Lost" in these guidelines). Accordingly, LDLT editions follow West's suggestion to use braces to indicate editorial deletions.
surplus signifies text identified by the editor as added by someone other than the original author.

div.head: Crux
div.p: † † = Text deemed by the editor to be irredeemably corrupt.
sic indicates that the text is readable but not understandable. In this usage it is not paired with its customary partner corr because the nature of a crux is that it cannot be corrected.

p.quote: … subiectisque eas rotis funibus iumentisque †obiectis† derectis plateis in quamcumque erat uisum partem mouebant

egXML.p: … subiectisque eas rotis funibus iumentisque obiectis derectis plateis in quamcumque erat uisum partem mouebant

div.head: Apparatus Fontium
div.p: In texts with many direct and indirect references to other sources, it may be desirable to include an apparatus fontium to alert readers to the sources. All of the elements of the citation will be incorporated into the main edition text, but they will not effect the display of the text itself. Bibliographic information about the source of the quotation or reference will be displayed or printed separately.
cit (cited quotation) contains a quotation (in quote) from another source or a reference (in ref) to another source, together with bibliographical information about the source (in bibl.
quote (quotation) contains a phrase or passage attributable to some agency external to the text.
ref (reference) contains a reference to a phrase or passage attributable to some agency external to the text.
bibl (bibliographic citation) contains the information required to retrieve the source of the quotation or reference. If a digital copy of the source is available, a link can be provided in ref.
Example of a quotation to be cited in the apparatus fontium:

egXML.p:
Item aliud verbum culpaverunt:
per tunicam squalentem auro latus haurit apertum
Verg. G. 3.4

div.p: Example of a reference to be cited in the apparatus fontium:

egXML.p: Probatio minoris per Boethium De TrinitateBoethius De Trin. c. 4 (ed. R. Peiper 159; PL 64, 1353C): dicit quod septem praedicamenta non dicunt absolutas res, sed tantum respectus.

div.p: In the edition text, the text would be displayed or printed without interruption (i.e., Probatio minoris per Boethium De Trinitate: dicit quod septem praedicamenta non dicunt absolutas res, sed tantum respectus). The apparatus fontium would include the following entry: "Boethius De Trin. c. 4 (ed. R. Peiper 159; PL 64, 1353C).
If it is desirable to provide the text of the reference, it may be inserted after bibl:

egXML.p: Probatio minoris per Boethium De TrinitateBoethius De Trin. c. 4 (ed. R. Peiper 159; PL 64, 1353C): Iamne patet quae sit differentia praedicationum? Quod aliae quidem quasi rem monstrant, aliae vero quasi circumstantias rei; quodque illa quae ita praedicantur, ut esse aliquid rem ostendant, illa vero ut non esse, sed potius extrinsecus aliquid quodam modo adfigant?: dicit quod septem praedicamenta non dicunt absolutas res, sed tantum respectus.

div.head: Apparatus Criticus
div.p: This section provides models for handling the different kinds of entries that occur in an apparatus criticus. It uses the terminology, elements, and attributes of the TEI's module for the critical apparatus, but it also defines terms specific to the encoding of LDLT editions. It is not a how-to manual for composing an apparatus criticus. For that, the reader is encouraged to study the items in the bibliography for this section. Rather, these guidelines present a model for semantically encoding the information to be included in the apparatus criticus of a critical edition.
In a digital context, critical editions encoded according to these guidelines will have certain interactive features:

list.item: Readings from manuscripts and other sources can be filtered in or out of the text.
Certain types of variant readings (e.g., orthographic variants, conjectures, corrections) can be filtered in or out of the text.
A variant reading can be swapped into the text so that it can be viewed in situ.
Line transpositions can be activated and viewed in the text.

div.head: Concepts and Definitions
div.p:
The apparatus criticus is where editors assemble the variant readings from witnesses and sources that they believe to be important for establishing the text, occasionally with brief comments, bibliographical citations, and palaeographical details. This section explains what the following terms mean in these guidelines:
reading
emendation
conjecture
witness
hand
source
order

div.head: Readings
div.p: In the context of a critical edition, "reading" is the generic term for any unit of information that has meaning in constituting the text of the edition. A critical edition contains two types of reading: lemma and variant.

A lemma is a word or phrase (or the absence thereof) judged by the editor to be authentic, accurate, and/or authoritative. It may be attested by documentary sources (e.g., a manuscript, an early edition) or it may be an emendation. Lemmata constitute the text printed in the main portion of a critical edition.

A variant reading is some a word or phrase (or absence thereof) judged by the editor to be unsatisfactory for linguistic and/or stylistic reasons, but of interest in establishing the text. These readings are "variants" insofar as they vary from what the editor has judged to be the lemmata. A variant reading may be attested by a manuscript or it may be a conjecture or a correction. Variant readings constitute the text printed in the apparatus criticus.
An emendation is a reading that is not supported by documentary evidence, but is expressly proposed by some person (possibly the editor) and accepted by the editor into the main text of an edition.

A conjecture is a reading that is not supported by known documentary evidence, but is proposed by some person and determined by an editor to be worthy of consideration in establishing the text, but not to be printed in the main text of the edition.

Correction describes any attempt by the original copyist or some other hand to alter a witness' reading, whether or not the result matches the lemma of the current edition. Whether or not the result of a correction is "correct" is a matter of perspective. Opinions can differ from editor to editor about what the "correct" reading is, which is why having more than one critical edition of a text is not redundant. Similarly, copyists and other users of manuscripts have their own idea of what the "correct" reading is. The original copyist might notice a slip of the pen in his own work and correct it. A later hand might correct a mistake missed by the copyist. Another reader comparing two manuscripts might "correct" one of them based on the other's reading. In all of these cases, the motivation is to correct what is perceived to be incorrect. For all of these reasons, "correction" is used in these guidelines to refer to an attempt to alter existing text so that it conforms to some perceived standard, whether or not that standard matches the editor's view of what the correct reading might be.
The next two sections discuss where readings are found, i.e., in witnesses and sources.

div.head: Witnesses
div.p: A witness may be a manuscript (more properly, the individual hands that wrote in it—see below) or an early printed edition (e.g., editio princeps) that may preserve the readings of a single manuscript.

The physical object referred to as a manuscript is not itself a witness. Rather, it preserves a record of the activities of the copyist(s), rubricator(s), corrector(s), and/or other annotator(s) who wrote on its pages, each of whom might be a witness to a different exemplar. At the very least, they represent different perceptions of the same exemplar. By synechdoche, those people are referred to as "hands." These hands are not to be confused with the drawings of hands, known as manicules, that sometimes appear in the margins of manuscripts to point out passages of interest. The manuscript's hands are represented by superscript numerals appended to its siglum. A change in number, however, does not necessarily indicate a change of person. For example, the copyist and corrector might be one and the same person, but it can be important to distinguish them, since they represent different views of the text. Unfortunately, confusion arises from the practice of assigning numbers only to hands subsequent to the original copyist. That is, the siglum by itself (i.e., without a superscript numeral) is understood to represent the hand of the original copyist, and every subsequent hand is numbered in descending order from "1". Strictly speaking, the original copyist is "hand zero," but adding a superscript zero to every siglum would be redundant, since it can be inferred from the absence of a numeral that the original copyist is meant.

In some cases, it is not necessary, possible, or desirable to make such a sharp distinction between hands. It may be sufficient instead to refer to hands other than the original copyist with the general manus recentior, or m.r. ("a later hand"). However the editor decides to represent the activities of a manuscript's hands and the relationships between them, an explanation should be provided in the preface.

In sum, for the purposes of these guidelines, manuscript hands are witnesses, and the following scheme should be used to indicate them:
siglum without a superscript number (= "hand zero"): the original copyist.
siglum with superscript 1 (= "hand one"): a hand that wrote in the manuscript after the original copyist wrote the text, even if it belongs to the original copyist.
siglum with superscript 2 (="hand two"): a hand that wrote at the same time or later than hand one.
etc.

div.head: Source
div.p: A source may be any modern critical edition, commentary, article, review, or other item (e.g., personal correspondence) in which an argument about the text has been advanced.

div.head: Order
div.p: Order: As in traditional printed editions, the order in which certain information is presented has meaning in LDLT editions, though the order's meaning is not itself explicitly encoded. Editors should follow the recommendations of West (87–88) on the issue of order. In brief:

list.item: Readings are presented in the following order of precedence: direct manuscript tradition, indirect tradition, conjectures (in descending order of merit, as determined by the editor).
Manuscripts should be given a regular order for citation, though editors may deviate from the practice for the sake of clarity.

div.head: Encoding Specifications for the Apparatus Criticus
div.p: To put the concepts discussed above into practice, the following attributes and elements are required:
app (apparatus entry) contains the lemma and readings for a single entry in the apparatus criticus, although it and its contents may be nested inside of another app.

lem (lemma) contains a reading judged by the editor to be authentic, or as close as possible to it. This type of reading constitutes the text of the initial state (i.e., when first opened) of the main portion of an LDLT edition. A lemma may be an absence of text, if the editor has reason to doubt the authenticity of the extant readings.

rdg (reading) contains some text (or absence of text) witnessed by a manuscript or found in an early printed edition where it is not expressly proposed, but judged by the editor to be unsatisfactory or corrupt for linguistic and/or stylistic reasons. This text is initially in the apparatus criticus, but it may be swapped with the lemma in the LDLT viewer.
wit (witness) includes any manuscript(s) (or manuscript hands) or early printed edition(s) (esp. without an apparatus or commentary; i.e., editiones vetustiores).
source (source) includes any printed edition(s) or other scholarly work(s) (e.g., article, textual note, commentary) addressing an aspect of the text.
wit contains general information about a reading or a group of witnesses.
witDetail (witness detail) contains information about a particular witness (wit) to a lemma (lem) or reading (rdg).
note (note) contains editorial comments, bibliographical references, or other information pertaining to the apparatus entry.

In traditional printed editions, the lemma may appear in the apparatus criticus for the purpose of disambiguation (e.g., if there are two instances of the word in the same line or if the degree of variance makes it difficult to infer the lemma), but more often the lemma must be inferred. This can lead to confusion and frustration, particularly in readers not used to navigating a critical edition. Moreover, variant readings are sequestered from the edition text and displayed at the bottom of the page, an arrangement that can lead to false impressions about the certainty and reliability of the edition text.

In the TEI's model for the critical apparatus, which is the basis for these guidelines, each entry includes the lemma and its variants. How that information is displayed or printed is a separate issue, but at least the relationship between the lemma and the variant readings is explicitly encoded. In digital representations of an edition encoded according to the guidelines presented here, readings may be swapped into or out of the edition text, but the editor's determination about what is the lemma and what is a variant remains encoded to preserve the argument the edition makes about the text. In this way, it is possible for readers to experience many versions of a text in addition to the edition's reference state (i.e., its default setting). The variety of readings depends on what the editor decides to encode, and it is expected that those decisions will be explained in the preface.

The patterns displayed below are designed to handle the various kinds of information conveyed in a typical apparatus criticus, including readings ante correctionem and in rasura, among other paleographical and editorial details. They were developed through a joint effort of the Digital Latin Library project and LombardPress. Contributors: Samuel J. Huskey, Hugh Cayless, Tom Elliott, Jeffrey C. Witt, Michael Stenskjær Christensen, and Nicolas Vaughan.

div.head: Basic Reporting of a Variant Reading
div.p: The most basic type of apparatus entry reports only a variant reading, without editorial comment or a description of palaeographical details. The pattern is as follows:

In other words, app begins the apparatus entry, followed by lem, which contains the lemma for the entry. The lemma may be a single word or phrase or the omission of a word or phrase. The variant reading follows, contained in rdg. The attribute wit lists the witness for the variant. The hash or pound sign (#) before the siglum for the witness indicates that the witness has been described elsewhere in the edition, making it possible to retrieve that information through a link to it, if desired.
If there is more than one witness for a reading, the sigla should be values for wit separated by spaces.
If there is more than one variant reading to be reported, new rdg elements should be added for each one.
If it is desirable to indicate that a variant appears in both a manuscript and a modern edition or other source, the same pattern applies, with the addition of source.

div.head: Examples of basic apparatus criticus entries
div.p: At Calp. 1.2 (quamvis et madidis incumbant praela racemis), the manuscript P has praeda where the lemma is praela. In a traditional apparatus criticus, this would be printed as follows: 2 praeda P.
The following pattern demonstrates how to encode the entry in XML:

egXML.l: quamvis et madidis incumbant praela praeda racemis

div.p: This encoding can be rendered in the traditional manner, or it can be used in an interactive apparatus to swap the variant with the lemma in the main edition text.
The lemma quamvis in the same line demonstrates how to indicate that a variant has more than one witness:

egXML.l: quamvis quatinus et madidis incumbant praela racemis

div.p: The witnesses are listed here in chronological order, but an editor may wish to use a different ordering principle. The order should be described and explained in the preface.
The following example demonstrates how to encode a reading supported by a witness and a source.

div.head: Additions, Deletions, and Omissions
div.p: The following sections provide guidelines for representing additions, deletions, and omissions in particular witnesses, as opposed to the tradition as a whole (for which see the section "Symbols Commonly Used in the Text of a Critical Edition"). In most cases, additions, deletions, and omissions will be encoded in combination with each other as part of a correction, but since it is possible that they would be encountered by themselves (e.g., addition of a reading in the margin), it seems best to treat them individually here.
There are two methods of encoding additions and deletions: prose description and semantic markup. Both are demonstrated in each of the following sections.

div.head: Additions
div.p: add (addition) contains text that has been added.

place indicates the placed where the text has been added. Possible values:
above: above the line (suprascr. = superscriptum/a)
below: below the line (subscr. = subscriptum/a)
bottom: bottom of the page (ad fin. = ad finem
inline: within the body of the original text (in textu)
inRas: in the space where text has been erased. (in ras. = in rasura)
margin: right, left, or both (in mg. = in margine)
top: at the top of the page (ad init. = ad initium
witDetail (witness detail) contains a prose description of the addition.
Example: The copyist of manuscript G has the lemma certare, but a later hand has added the variant reading certate in the margin.
The prose description method uses witDetail to describe the addition:
The semantic markup method uses add to encode the addition:
The same information is presented in both cases, but the semantic markup version would support querying and filtering on readings added in the margin (or elsewhere).

div.head: Deletions
div.p: Normally, deletions are part of a correction.

div.head: Omission
div.p: This section explains how to encode omission of text from a witness.

For example, the witness known as "P" has omitted the word pecus from the following text: securo custode pecus nocturnaque pastor. The traditional apparatus criticus indicates the omission as follows:
pecus om. P
In these guidelines, the omission is represented by a so-called "self-closing" rdg (<rdg/>):
The same model applies to the omission of an entire line of verse, but in that case app has type="lineOmission" and lem contains the entire line, with the omission marked by a self-closing rdg:

lem.l: et spument rauco ferventia musta susurro.

div.p: This will be displayed in the apparatus criticus as vers. om. nh

div.head: Corrections
div.p: Correction has been discussed at length in the section "Concepts and Definitions." In short, for the purposes of these guidelines, "correction" describes any attempt by the original copyist or some other hand to alter a witness' reading, whether or not the result matches the lemma of the current edition.

Since the amount of detail to report is a matter for editors to decide, this section describes a range of options for encoding corrections. All are acceptable and will be supported by the LDLT's viewer application. When determining the method to use, editors should bear in mind not only the amount of detail necessary to communicate the nature of a correction, but also the functionality they want their edition to support. The subsections below include discussions intended to help editors make those determinations.

div.head: Correction as Metadata
div.p: Editors have devised creative ways of reporting corrections. The simplest method is to report readings and annotate them with ante correctionem, post correctionem, or something similar. Another method is to add abbreviations for those phrases as superscript notations on manuscript sigla (e.g., Bac, Bpc). Sometimes it is necessary to provide more detail about the method of correction, in which cases editors will either describe the correction (e.g., t exp., r add. s.l.) or they will try to represent it typographically (e.g., referṭre). Some rely on superscript notation for all of these details (e.g., Pcsl = P correctio supra lineam).

The different methods have advantages and disadvantages, but they all effectively demonstrate that correction is a complex subject. Even the word "correction" is problematic, since it can refer to the result of a process or the process itself. If correction is to be represented faithfully in a digital critical edition, we must analyze the information it conveys.

Aside from judgments about correctness, "correction" necessarily involves at least four kinds of information:
an original reading
an altered form of the original reading
an agent or agents (i.e., the correcting hand or hands)
a method or methods of correction (i.e., deletion, addition above the line, etc.) Since the primary mission of an apparatus criticus is to report variant readings, it is useful to think of the original reading and the altered form of the original reading as the data and the information about agency and method as metadata, or data about the data. But "original form" and "altered form" can be analyzed further into states (original and altered), leaving two readings as the data, with the following metadata:
state (original, altered)
correspondence (showing that the two readings are related to each other through correction)
agent or agents
method or methods of correction

Not all of these metadata items will be required in every instance. The original reading, for example, will obviously not have an agent (beyond the witness to the reading) or a method of correction, but it will have a state (original). It might have a correspondence to show that it is related to its altered form, if one is provided, but it is not always necessary to report the altered form. For example, if the altered form is the lemma in the main text of the edition, it is sufficient to report the original form with a note that it was corrected (the inference being that it was corrected to the "correct" form of the lemma if no other form is reported). Similarly, it may not be necessary to report the method of correction.

With regard to reporting the method of correction, the LDLT supports two approaches, prose description and typographical depiction. The former simply requires a succinct description of the correction (e.g., t add. s.l.).
The latter requires the correction to be encoded using techniques described elsewhere in these guidelines:
Editors should declare in the preface which method(s) they have adopted so that users will know to what extent the data about corrections is structured.

Classifying information related to correction as metadata supports a variety of functions. In addition to preserving the ability to swap readings in an out of the text described elsewhere in these guidelines, it will allow querying of information specific to certain witnesses, listing of all apparatus entries involving correction, filtering of variants with corrected forms, and more.
The following sections demonstrate how correction information should be encoded to take advantage of this functionality.

div.head: Correction: Basics
div.p: Readings before and after correction are reported as any other readings, i.e., with rdg inside of app. The details of the correction are contained in witDetail, with the use of several attributes to determine how the information is processed.
witDetail (witness detail) may be empty or it may contain a prose description or a semantically encoded representation of a correction.
wit (witness) has as its value the machine-readable siglum of the witness that has the correction.
target has as its value the xml:id of the reading in question.
corresp (corresponds) has as its value the xml:id of the related reading (i.e., the original reading corresponds to the corrected reading).

type has one of the following values to classify the correction. Possible values:
correction-original: the original reading, i.e., before correction (ante correctionem or a.c.)
correction-altered: the altered reading, i.e., after correction (post correctionem or p.c.)

div.head: Simple Correction
div.p: Example: referre] referte E (a.c.)

If there is only one variant reading with one witness, and that reading has been corrected so that it matches what is printed in the main text of the edition, or if it is otherwise obvious what the result of the correction is, it is not necessary to report the corrected form, since that can be inferred from the absence of a different corrected form. This would be encoded as follows:

corresp points to the lem to indicate that the corrected form matches the lemma. The witDetail is empty (i.e., "self-closing") because the abbreviation "a.c." can be inserted automatically during processing.
If it is desirable to note how the correction was made, that information can be inserted as a value for witDetail. See the section "Describing Corrections" for more information.

div.head: Correction: Readings Before and After Correction
div.p: Example: cortice N2 (p.c., rt add. in ras.) P V, co[..]ice N (a.c.), codice G A

In this example, witness N originally had co and ice with an erasure of two characters between them. A correcting hand has inserted the letters "r" and "t" in the erasure. The corrected form (cortice) matches the reading in witnesses P and V. Another reading is present in witnesses G and A. It is important to report both the original and the corrected readings in witness N so that there is no ambiguity.

div.head: Conjecture and Emendation
div.p: As explained in the section Concepts and Definitions, conjectures are readings that are not supported by documentary evidence, but are instead proposed by someone and considered by the editor to be worthy of inclusion in a critical edition. A conjecture is called an emendation if it is adopted as the official reading of a particular criticial edition's main text. In other words, for the purposes of these guidelines, an emendation is a successful conjecture. But above all, conjectures and emendations are readings, and they are encoded as such in LDLT editions.

Traditionally, conjectures and emendations have been annotated in various ways in critical editions (e.g., ci. or conj. for coniecit, em. or emend. for emendavit, among others). They should be annotated in digital editions, too, both to facilitate their identification, and to enable features such as filtering and searching for them. The annotation is accomplished with type.

Since an emendation is a conjecture that has been adopted for the main text of the edition, only lem can have type with value "emendation." It could be inferred that a lemma with source only is an emendation, but in the interest of being explicit, an emendation should be annotated accordingly. Conversely, only rdg may have type with value "conjecture." It could be inferred that a reading with source only is a conjecture, but it is best to be explicit in the identification.
The following example demonstrates how to encode both an emendation and a conjecture.
This encoding will produce the following output: plenumque] conj. Haupt (prob. Keene et Schenkl), primumque ω edd., rivumque Baehr., pronumque C. Schenkl.
If someone has proposed multiple conjectures, they should be contained in rdgGrp with type and value "conjecture."
This would be displayed as pallenti] ridenti vel varianti vel vernanti vel roranti conj. Heins.
